articles.title: More than 30% of this century’s science Nobel prizewinners immigrated: see their journeys
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 09 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03247-6The most common destination for eventual Nobel laureates in physics, chemistry and medicine since 2000 is the United States, Nature has found.
articles.content:
Omar Yaghi, who was awarded a Nobel Prize in Chemistry on Wednesday, emigrated from Jordan to the United States as a teenager.Credit: Brittany Hosea-Small/UC Berkeley

Of the 202 Nobel laureates in physics, chemistry and medicine this century, less than 70% hail from the country in which they were awarded their prize. The remaining 63 laureates left their country of birth before winning a Nobel prize, sometimes crossing international borders more than once, a Nature analysis shows (see ‘Nobel flows’).

Among the Nobel prizewinners who emigrated to other countries are two of three chemistry winners announced on Wednesday. Richard Robson was born in the United Kingdom but now lives in Australia. And Omar Yaghi, who is now a US resident, became the first Jordanian-born Nobel laureate in science. Two of the three physics winners for 2025 are also immigrants: Michel Devoret was born in France and John Clarke in the United Kingdom, but both are US residents.

Immigrants have long played an important part on the Nobel stage, including illustrious scientists such as Albert Einstein, who moved from his birthplace in Germany to Switzerland (and later to the United States), and Marie Curie, who left her native Poland to work in France. That’s because the most fruitful scientific opportunities — the best training, equipment and research communities — are scattered across the globe. “Talent can be born anywhere, but opportunities are not,” says Ina Ganguli, an economist at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. “I think that’s the reason we see so many foreign Nobel laureates.”

The new analysis comes as the international flow of scientists and students faces growing obstacles. In the United States, for example, rampant grant cuts and stricter immigration policies implemented this year by the administration of President Donald Trump threaten a looming ‘brain drain’. Such restrictions “will slow the rate of highly novel research, period”, says Caroline Wagner, a specialist in science and technology policy at the Ohio State University in Columbus. The White House did not respond to a request for comment about the effects of Trump’s policies.

Meanwhile, Australia has capped the number of international students that its institutions can enrol each year, and Japan proposed cutting financial support to graduate students from other countries.

Common destination

Among those who have already crossed borders is Andre Geim, a physicist at the University of Manchester, UK, and a 2010 physics laureate. Born in Russia to German parents, Geim says he “bounced around like a pinball” throughout his research career, holding positions in Russia, Denmark, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands. “If you stay put your whole life, you miss half the game,” he says.

Of the 63 laureates who won the prize after moving out of their birth countries, 41 lived in the United States when their Nobel was awarded. After the Second World War, the United States became a global hub for science, Ganguli says. International researchers flocked there for its generous grants and top universities (see ‘Nobel laureate stomping grounds’). “What we have in the US is unique. It’s a destination for top students and scientists,” says Ganguli. The next most popular landing place was the United Kingdom, which was home to seven of the Nobel prizewinners who had emigrated by the time they got the fateful phone call from Stockholm.

But, the United Kingdom also saw future prizewinners leave. Thirteen Nobel prizewinners who were born there won the prize while living elsewhere (see ‘Points of departure’), perhaps lured by higher salaries and more prestigious positions, Wagner says. Substantial numbers of future Nobel laureates also left Germany, with six expatriate prizewinners, as well as Japan, France and Russia, each with four expatriate laureates.

Among the science categories of the Nobel prizes, physics has the highest proportion of foreign-born laureates so far this century: 37% (see ‘Disciplines differ’). Trailing just behind is chemistry at 33%, and finally, medicine at 23%. Physics probably takes the lead because of its equipment-heavy nature, according to Wagner. The pricey colliders, reactors, lasers, detectors and telescopes that are needed for top-notch physics research reside mainly in a few leading nations. “Thus, the top research talent will likely go to places with top equipment. Medicine is not an equipment-heavy field, so it is easier to stay home,” Wagner says.

Moving on

The future of immigration’s interplay with the Nobels is murky. Australia, Canada and the United Kingdom have all enacted restrictions that have reduced the number of university students from abroad. The Trump administration has slashed billions of dollars in scientific research grants so far this year. And a new US policy charges US$100,000 per application for an H-1B visa, which some foreign-born researchers rely on to work in the United States.

articles.personality_title: Over 30% of Nobel Science Winners This Century Moved Countries to Advance Their Work
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Since 2000, many scientists who won Nobel Prizes in physics, chemistry, and medicine were born in one country but won the award while living in another. This shows how moving to places with better research opportunities can help scientists succeed.

**What happened** – A study found that out of 202 Nobel laureates this century, 63 had left their birth countries before winning. For example, Omar Yaghi, born in Jordan, moved to the United States and won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2025. Many winners moved to the US, which is the most common destination, followed by the United Kingdom and Australia.

**Impact** – This movement is important because top scientific work often needs special equipment, funding, and strong research communities found in certain countries. Physics winners especially tend to move because their work depends on expensive machines. The study also shows that immigration helps science grow by allowing talented people to find the best places to work.

**What's next step** – New policies in countries like the US, Australia, and the UK are making it harder for scientists and students to move. These changes could slow down important scientific discoveries in the future. Experts worry that fewer immigrants might reduce the number of Nobel-level breakthroughs.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Many top scientists move across countries to access better resources, which helps them achieve major discoveries like Nobel Prizes, but new immigration rules may threaten this valuable exchange.
articles.personality_title_fr: Plus de 30 % des lauréats du prix Nobel de science de ce siècle ont changé de pays pour avancer dans leurs recherches
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis 2000, de nombreux scientifiques ayant remporté un prix Nobel en physique, chimie et médecine sont nés dans un pays mais ont gagné le prix en vivant dans un autre. Cela montre que déménager vers des lieux offrant de meilleures opportunités de recherche peut aider au succès.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Une étude a révélé que sur 202 lauréats du Nobel ce siècle, 63 avaient quitté leur pays natal avant de gagner. Par exemple, Omar Yaghi, né en Jordanie, a déménagé aux États-Unis et a reçu le prix Nobel de chimie en 2025. Beaucoup de lauréats ont choisi les États-Unis, destination la plus fréquente, suivis du Royaume-Uni et de l’Australie.

**Impact** – Ce déplacement est important car les travaux scientifiques de pointe nécessitent souvent des équipements spéciaux, des financements et des communautés de recherche fortes, présents dans certains pays. Les lauréats en physique bougent particulièrement car leur travail dépend d’appareils coûteux. L’étude montre aussi que l’immigration favorise la science en permettant aux talents de trouver les meilleurs endroits pour travailler.

**Prochaines étapes** – De nouvelles politiques aux États-Unis, en Australie et au Royaume-Uni rendent plus difficile la mobilité des scientifiques et étudiants. Ces changements pourraient ralentir les découvertes scientifiques importantes à l’avenir. Des experts craignent qu’une baisse de l’immigration réduise le nombre de percées au niveau Nobel.

**Résumé en une phrase** – De nombreux grands scientifiques changent de pays pour accéder à de meilleures ressources, ce qui les aide à réaliser des découvertes majeures comme les prix Nobel, mais les nouvelles règles d’immigration risquent de menacer cet échange précieux.
articles.personality_title_es: Más del 30 % de los ganadores del Nobel de ciencia de este siglo se mudaron de país para avanzar en su trabajo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Desde el año 2000, muchos científicos que ganaron premios Nobel en física, química y medicina nacieron en un país, pero ganaron el premio mientras vivían en otro. Esto muestra cómo mudarse a lugares con mejores oportunidades de investigación puede ayudar a los científicos a tener éxito.

**Qué pasó** – Un estudio encontró que de 202 ganadores del Nobel en este siglo, 63 se habían ido de su país natal antes de ganar. Por ejemplo, Omar Yaghi, nacido en Jordania, se mudó a Estados Unidos y ganó el premio Nobel de Química en 2025. Muchos ganadores se mudaron a Estados Unidos, que es el destino más común, seguido por Reino Unido y Australia.

**Impacto** – Este movimiento es importante porque el trabajo científico avanzado a menudo necesita equipos especiales, financiamiento y comunidades fuertes de investigación que se encuentran en ciertos países. Los ganadores de física se mudan más porque su trabajo depende de máquinas costosas. El estudio también muestra que la inmigración ayuda a la ciencia al permitir que los talentos encuentren los mejores lugares para trabajar.

**Pasos siguientes** – Nuevas políticas en países como Estados Unidos, Australia y Reino Unido están dificultando que científicos y estudiantes se muden. Estos cambios podrían hacer que los descubrimientos científicos importantes se ralenticen en el futuro. Los expertos temen que menos inmigrantes puedan reducir el número de avances a nivel Nobel.

**Frase clave** – Muchos científicos destacados se mudan entre países para acceder a mejores recursos, lo que les ayuda a lograr grandes descubrimientos como los premios Nobel, pero las nuevas reglas de inmigración pueden amenazar este valioso intercambio.

articles.title: Rebuilding Gaza: don’t sideline Palestinian scientists, say experts
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 10 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03324-wResearchers warn against ‘top down’ solutions as ceasefire is agreed in the first phase of a peace deal.
articles.content:
Researchers who study post-war reconstruction have told Nature that the recovery of public health, environment, higher education and research in Gaza will not succeed unless it is led by experts from the Palestinian territory.

Their warning comes amid images of jubilant scenes in Gaza yesterday as negotiators in Egypt sealed the first phase of US President Donald Trump’s ceasefire plan, which today was ratified by Israel's cabinet.

Israel’s bombardment and ground offensive, which has killed more than 67,000 people, began soon after the Hamas attacks of 7 October 2023, in which 1,200 people were killed and 251 were taken hostage.

Under Trump’s plan, Hamas is expected to disarm, release the remaining hostages and play no part in Gaza’s governance. Israel’s government will suspend military action, withdraw its forces to an agreed position, free a number of Palestinian people it is holding in captivity, allow more aid into Gaza and permit United Nations agencies to operate in the territory. The precise details of how all this will be implemented have not been announced.

“We woke up [yesterday] morning to happy, long-awaited news. There are so many celebrations here in Gaza right now,” says Farid Al-Qeeq, a researcher in urban planning and former president of Gaza University.

The researchers Nature interviewed for this article say it’s important that reconstruction is led by Palestinian communities. They are voicing these concerns now because Palestinian organizations have not been named as having a leadership role in Trump’s plan.

Since the first attacks, Israel's troops have almost completely destroyed Gaza’s physical infrastructure — including hospitals, other health-care facilities and water and sanitation.

By the end of August, a time when there were severe restrictions to aid getting through, more than half a million people were experiencing famine, the Famine Review Committee, an independent group of experts, concluded. Nearly 55,000 children below the age of five — are acutely malnourished, according to data published in The Lancet on 8 September1.

Source: Ref. 1

More than 2,200 medical and education personnel have been killed, according to data published by the Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics based in Ramallah in the West Bank. Almost four-fifths of higher-education campuses have been damaged or destroyed, and 88,000 students at those institutions have been forced to put their studies on hold, according to the UN’s science agency UNESCO, based in Paris.

“It’s important to understand the enormity of the scale of destruction”, says Savo Heleta, a researcher at Nelson Mandela University in South Africa who studies post-conflict higher education and aid flows to Palestinian universities. In a yet-to-be published paper, Heleta estimates that the war has damaged at least US$222 million worth of higher-education infrastructure. Rebuilding, he says, would need nearly five times that, at around $1 billion, because of the cost of clearing debris and removing unexploded bombs.

Heleta also says that if past trends are a guide to the future, then “countries from the Gulf and Turkey are likely to be the main donors” for reconstruction. He adds that in previous years, aid for universities amounted to a maximum of just $20 million per year.

Amani Al-Mqadma, head of international relations for the Islamic University of Gaza, and a co-author of ‘Resilience in the rubble’, a report assessing the needs of higher education in Gaza, says that the territory’s priorities extend beyond physical reconstruction. They must also include sustaining online education until physical spaces are rebuilt; mental-health support for students and staff; and reconnecting researchers to the world through conferences, visits and scholarships. Because higher-education institutions in Gaza rely mostly on income from tuition fees, Al-Mqadma calls for aid to cover students’ fees to keep universities alive.

Let Palestinians lead

Gaza’s scientific institutions should be crucial partners in the reconstruction efforts, says Al-Mqadma, who is currently based at the University of Edinburgh, UK. “These academics possess unparalleled local knowledge and a deep understanding of their land.” Moreover, “decisions about the region’s future must be informed by extensive input from the communities who will be most affected”, adds Naomi Rintoul-Hynes, a soil scientist at Canterbury Christ Church University in the UK, who is studying the environmental impact on Gaza of the war.

People gather in Hostages Square in Tel Aviv on 9 October to celebrate the ceasefire agreement to end the war in Gaza.Credit: Saeed Qaq/Anadolu via Getty

Under Trump’s plan, a “technocratic” committee of Palestinian and international experts will be appointed to run public services. It will be under the oversight of an international body of decision makers, likely at the level of heads of government and called the Board of Peace. The board will be chaired by Trump and will include former UK prime minister Tony Blair.

Sultan Barakat, a public policy researcher at Hamad Bin Khalifa University in Qatar, says many respected academics will not participate in the committee if it turns out to be “the management of an occupation”.

“There will be a lot of questioning around this committee”, says Barakat, who is co-author of a report, ‘Gaza: leadership and reconstruction for the day after’, published last year.

articles.personality_title: Experts urge Palestinian leadership in Gaza’s rebuilding after ceasefire
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – After years of conflict, Gaza has suffered massive damage to its hospitals, schools, and homes. A recent ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas has opened the way for rebuilding the region, but experts warn that those efforts must involve local Palestinian scientists and leaders to succeed.

**What happened** – On 9 October 2025, negotiators agreed on the first phase of a peace plan that paused fighting in Gaza. This plan includes disarming Hamas and allowing more aid and United Nations agencies to operate in the area. However, the plan’s details do not clearly say how Palestinian experts and organizations will be involved in leading reconstruction.

**Impact** – Gaza’s infrastructure—especially hospitals, water systems, and universities—has been heavily damaged. More than 88,000 students had to stop their studies, and many medical workers lost their lives. Experts say that rebuilding will require about $1 billion, much more than past aid levels. Importantly, researchers stress that local scientists and educators understand Gaza’s needs best. If they are sidelined, recovery efforts may fail to address key problems like mental health support, online education, and community priorities.

**What’s next step** – The next challenge is to ensure Palestinian experts play a major role in planning and managing Gaza’s recovery. An international committee is being set up to oversee public services, but some worry it might not fully represent local voices. How this committee develops and includes Palestinian leadership will shape the success of rebuilding efforts moving forward.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For Gaza’s recovery to work well, Palestinian scientists and local leaders must guide rebuilding efforts alongside international support.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les experts appellent à un leadership palestinien pour la reconstruction de Gaza après le cessez-le-feu
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Après des années de conflit, Gaza a subi d’importants dégâts dans ses hôpitaux, ses écoles et ses logements. Un récent accord de cessez-le-feu entre Israël et le Hamas ouvre la voie à la reconstruction, mais les experts avertissent que ces efforts doivent impliquer les scientifiques et les responsables palestiniens locaux pour réussir.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 9 octobre 2025, des négociateurs ont convenu de la première phase d’un plan de paix qui a suspendu les combats à Gaza. Ce plan prévoit le désarmement du Hamas et l’autorisation d’une aide accrue ainsi que l’intervention d’agences des Nations Unies. Cependant, les détails du plan ne précisent pas clairement comment les experts et organisations palestiniens seront impliqués dans la direction de la reconstruction.

**Impact** – Les infrastructures de Gaza — en particulier les hôpitaux, les systèmes d’eau et les universités — ont été gravement endommagées. Plus de 88 000 étudiants ont dû interrompre leurs études et de nombreux professionnels de la santé ont perdu la vie. Les experts estiment que la reconstruction nécessitera environ un milliard de dollars, bien plus que les niveaux d’aide précédents. Ils insistent sur le fait que les scientifiques et éducateurs locaux comprennent le mieux les besoins de Gaza. S’ils sont écartés, les efforts de reconstruction risquent de ne pas répondre aux problèmes clés comme le soutien en santé mentale, l’éducation en ligne et les priorités communautaires.

**Prochaine étape** – Le défi suivant est de garantir que les experts palestiniens jouent un rôle majeur dans la planification et la gestion de la reconstruction de Gaza. Un comité international est en cours de création pour superviser les services publics, mais certains craignent qu’il ne représente pas pleinement les voix locales. La manière dont ce comité se développera et inclura le leadership palestinien déterminera le succès des efforts de reconstruction.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Pour que la reconstruction de Gaza soit efficace, les scientifiques palestiniens et les leaders locaux doivent guider les efforts de reconstruction avec le soutien international.
articles.personality_title_es: Expertos piden liderazgo palestino en la reconstrucción de Gaza tras el alto al fuego
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Después de años de conflicto, Gaza ha sufrido daños graves en sus hospitales, escuelas y viviendas. Un reciente acuerdo de alto al fuego entre Israel y Hamas abre la puerta para reconstruir la región, pero expertos advierten que estos esfuerzos deben incluir a científicos y líderes palestinos locales para tener éxito.

**Qué pasó** – El 9 de octubre de 2025, negociadores acordaron la primera fase de un plan de paz que detuvo los combates en Gaza. Este plan incluye el desarme de Hamas y permitir más ayuda y la operación de agencias de las Naciones Unidas. Sin embargo, los detalles del plan no explican claramente cómo se involucrará a expertos y organizaciones palestinas para liderar la reconstrucción.

**Impacto** – La infraestructura de Gaza —especialmente hospitales, sistemas de agua y universidades— ha sido gravemente dañada. Más de 88,000 estudiantes tuvieron que detener sus estudios y muchos trabajadores médicos perdieron la vida. Los expertos dicen que la reconstrucción requerirá cerca de mil millones de dólares, mucho más que la ayuda anterior. Es importante que los científicos y educadores locales, que entienden mejor las necesidades de Gaza, lideren estos esfuerzos. Si se los excluye, la recuperación podría no cubrir problemas importantes como el apoyo a la salud mental, la educación en línea y las prioridades de la comunidad.

**Próximo paso** – El próximo desafío es asegurar que los expertos palestinos tengan un papel importante en planificar y dirigir la recuperación de Gaza. Se está formando un comité internacional para supervisar los servicios públicos, pero algunos temen que no represente adecuadamente las voces locales. Cómo se forme este comité y se incluya el liderazgo palestino será clave para el éxito de la reconstrucción.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Para que la recuperación de Gaza funcione bien, los científicos y líderes locales palestinos deben guiar los esfuerzos de reconstrucción junto con el apoyo internacional.
